nodes.text: IT change initiatives are far riskier than commonly believed because a disproportionate number produce extreme overruns (Black Swans) that can sink companies and careers
We analyzed a global sample of 1,471 IT projects, comparing planned budgets and benefits with actual costs and results

The sample was large (average project cost $167 million, largest $33 billion), drawn heavily from public agencies (92%) and U.S. projects (83%), and included ERP, management information, and CRM projects
Average cost overrun across the sample was 27%, but the distribution has a fat tail with many massive overruns
One in six projects in the sample was a Black Swan, with average cost overrun of about 200% and schedule overrun of almost 70%
By focusing on mean overruns (like 27%), managers and consultants underestimate the true risk posed by the high-frequency of extreme overages
Extreme IT project failures have caused CEO and CIO resignations and corporate collapse, exemplified by Levi Strauss, Kmart, Auto Windscreens, Toll Collect, and EADS/Airbus problems

Common causes of catastrophic IT project outcomes include high project complexity, extensive customization, incompatible legacy systems, inadequate financial controls, and limited product developers knowledge of software integration

Case examples: Levi Strauss SAP migration (budget < $5M led to $192.5M charge and CIO resignation), Kmart IT modernization contributed to bankruptcy, Airbus A380 wiring/configuration mismatches caused repeated delays and losses
Companies already under financial strain are especially vulnerable because an out-of-control IT project can compound existing problems and trigger failure

To manage Black Swan risk, firms should perform stress tests asking whether they can absorb a 400% overrun on their largest project with only 25 to 50 percent of benefits realized, and whether 15% of medium projects could exceed estimates by 200%

Managers should reduce risk by breaking large projects into limited-size modules, limiting complexity and duration, making contingency plans, and using improved forecasting such as reference class forecasting
Reference class forecasting uses outcomes from similar projects in other organizations to produce better estimates and is mandated for large public projects in some countries

A success case: Emirates NBD banking core system merger project limited schedule slip to 7% and cost overrun to 18% by resisting scope change, modularizing work, assembling the right team, preventing turnover, and focusing on readiness to go live
Therefore, top managers must actively oversee major IT initiatives, apply stress testing, adopt modularization and better forecasting, and treat IT change as a business issue to avoid Black Swans
